comment.author: 8374715@N06
comment._content: This is probably Walston Levi Locke. B Jan 24, 1896 in South Carolina, d Jul 5, 1993 in Charlotte, NC Found via Ancestry.com and good ol' Google. Poking around trying to determine who it was, I found an interview of him taken in1984 when he was 88 on Youtube. www.youtube.com/watch?v=qFh6Oscg3Vw

comment.author: 58031512@N02
comment._content: Uncle Walston Levi Locke worked at a rehabilitation facility for the war department in Washington from the early 1920's until he retired in the 1960's. He was a World War I veteran. I don't think he ever became an officer, and I don't recall him ever being referred to as "captain". The man in this photograph bears little resemblance to the images we have of Walston when he was in his 30's and 40's, but I will send a copy to his son in Florida, Walston, Jr., and see what he can tell me. One thing about it, this gentlemen might be a relative from another branch of the family, and this may help another Locke researcher, like myself, locate a missing relative...

comment.author: 32573662@N00
comment._content: A White House Historical Association book (snippet available online) mentions a Lieutenant E.P. Locke Jr. who in 1934 "handled White House projects for the Office of Public Buildings and Grounds of the National Park Service." It appears our lieutenant was promoted shortly thereafter, as several newspaper articles from '35-37 identify a Captain E.P. Locke as the "army engineer in charge of the White House physical plant". The Trenton Evening Times gives Locke's first name as Edwin in their 15 October 1937 edition. Sadly I can't find any info beyond that, but maybe others can sleuth out more now that we've got a full(ish) name?

comment.author: 8374715@N06
comment._content: He could be Edwin Allen Locke, Jr (1910-1999). Locke was very involved with the Truman Administration from what I've learned about him over the past half hour or so of internet sleuthing. He was one of the first ambassadors to Palestine/Israel from what I understand. If so, he'd only be about 25 or 26 in this image if it actually is from 1935. I found a decent image of Edwin Locke from 1946 at the Truman Library website from about the same angle, and I'd bet good money it was him. www.trumanlibrary.org/photographs/displayimage.php?pointe...

comment.author: 8374715@N06
comment._content: And here's an extremely interesting interview taken in 1953 on Youtube. www.youtube.com/watch?v=defuOt-ctoE

comment.author: 32573662@N00
comment._content: Edwin A. Locke gets mentioned a lot in the papers along with the White House, but not until the '40s, when he was tapped by Truman to be a "special presidential assistant" to work on governmental reorganization. Plus he wasn't in the military and probably wouldn't've been called Captain. Given the date on this photo, and the newspaper accounts from '35, my money's still on E.P. :)

comment.author: 8374715@N06
comment._content: Theres a mention of him in Stars and Stripes in 1945 as being appointed 'Special Representative to Foreign Governments' and as being the former holder of that position's 'longtime assistant'.   Theres also an elnistment record for an Edwin A Locke of Boston in March of 1941 witha  civilian career as a commercial artist.  The birthdate is off, but it could be him which would show a military record.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
And the mystery continues... 

I'm really enjoying this discussion!  Thank you all for keeping in touch.  I look forward to uncovering more.

Susannah

comment._content: This is not Edwin Allen Locke Jr- he was my mentor and was not yet working at the White House as he did later as Special Assisitant to President Truman
